text: The name 'Ghana' means 'Warrior King' and was the title of the kings of the medieval Ghana Empire.
Lake Volt is the largest man-made lake in the world by surface area.
Kente cloth originated from the Ashanti people and legend says it was inspired by a spider's web.
Ghana has a sanctuary for monkeys at Tafi Atome where they are considered sacred.
Fufu pounders often create rhythmic beats while preparing the meal, turning cooking into music.
Ghana was the first country in sub-Saharan Africa to gain independence from colonial rule in 1957.
Ghana is geographically closer to the center of the world (0°, 0°) than any other country.
Mole National Park is Ghana's largest wildlife refuge, home to elephants, leopards, and antelopes.
The Adinkra symbol 'Gye Nyame' signifies the supremacy of God and is unique to Ghana.
Jollof Rice wars between Ghana and Nigeria are a legendary, friendly culinary rivalry.
Ghana is the second-largest producer of cocoa beans in the world.
Elmina Castle, built in 1482, is the oldest European building in existence below the Sahara.
In Ghana, it is considered rude to use your left hand for greeting or eating.
Mount Afadja (Afadjato) is the highest mountain in Ghana, standing at 885 meters.
Kakum National Park features one of only three canopy walkways in Africa.
Yaa Asantewaa led the Ashanti war against the British in 1900 to protect the Golden Stool.
Kelewele is a popular spicy fried plantain snack often sold at night.
Funerals in Ghana are often elaborate, weekend-long celebrations of life.
The Prime Meridian places Ghana in the same time zone as London (GMT).
Ghana has over 1,000 species of butterflies, one of the highest densities in the world.
Kwame Nkrumah was voted Africa's 'Man of the Millennium' by BBC listeners.
Waakye is a dish of rice and beans cooked with red millet leaves for color.
Traditional chiefs are carried in palanquins during major festivals like Hodzwu.
Gold is one of Ghana's major exports, giving it the colonial name 'Gold Coast'.
The Wli Waterfalls is the highest waterfall in West Africa.
Accra became the capital of the Gold Coast in 1877, replacing Cape Coast.
The Volta River spans across much of the country, feeding the Akosombo Dam.
Names in Ghana often correspond to the day of the week a person was born (e.g., Kofi for Friday).
Banku and Tilapia is a staple dish, often eaten with fingers.
Boabeng-Fiema Monkey Sanctuary hosts mona monkeys that live peacefully with humans.
The Ashanti Empire was one of the most powerful kingdoms in Africa in the 18th century.
Ghana launched its first satellite, GhanaSat-1, into space in 2017.
Durbars are colorful festivals of chiefs and people, showcasing rich traditions.
Ghana shares borders with Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso, and Togo.
Shito is a famous hot black pepper sauce used with almost every meal.
Lake Bosomtwe is Ghana's only natural lake, formed in an ancient meteorite crater.
Okomfo Anokye is a legendary priest said to have conjured the Golden Stool from the sky.
Azonto is a communicative dance and music genre that originated in Ghana.
While English is official, there are over 80 languages spoken in Ghana.
Tro-tros are the colorful, slogan-decorated minibuses used for public transport.
WEB Du Bois, the famous civil rights activist, spent his final years in Ghana.
The meridian rock in Tema marks the exact line of Greenwich Meridian.
Shea butter comes from the Shea tree, which grows widely in Northern Ghana.
'Akwaaba' means Welcome, and you will see it everywhere in Ghana.
Kenkey is a sourdough dumpling made from fermented white corn, wrapped in husks.
The national football team is called the Black Stars, named after the star in the flag.
Ghana was a founding member of the Non-Aligned Movement during the Cold War.
Umbrella Rock in Koforidua is a huge rock naturally balanced in the shape of an umbrella.
Fantasy coffins in Ghana are custom-made to reflect the deceased's profession (e.g., a fish for a fisherman).
Ghana has 550 kilometers of coastline with beautiful sandy beaches.
